Dear Mr. Gloss:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
06/17/2025. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective action
plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Tyler Armstrong, Licensing Consultant

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records for
each employee and shall include documentation of
all of the following information prior to employment or
at the time specified in this rule:
(j) A written evaluation of the employee's
performance within 30 days of the completion of
the probationary period or within 180 days,
whichever is less, and a written evaluation of the
employee's performance annually thereafter.
One out of three applicable employee files reviewed did not contain a timely
performance evaluation.
CCI Rule 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio
(4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of
the direct supervision of staff, staff shall perform
variable interval, eye-on checks of residents. The
2

time between the variable interval checks shall not
exceed fifteen minutes.
A sample of overnight documentation showed that the facility was not consistently
conducting varied interval eyes-on checks of youth while they were asleep.
CCI Rule 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(3) The licensee shall document that each staff person
whose function is covered by these rules has
participated in a minimum of 50 clock hours of
planned training within the first year of employment
and a minimum of 25 clock hours of training annually
thereafter related to the employee's job function. At
least 16 of the 50 hours provided in the first year
shall be orientation provided prior to the assumption
of duties.
Two out of three applicable employee files reviewed did not contain enough
training hours required.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Technical assistance was provided regarding the formatting and consistency of
documentation needed at intake. In addition, technical assistance was provided to the
facility regarding the consistency of use of service plan templates across timeframes as
well as the approval of service plans in the absence of Case Manager Supervisors.
Technical assistance was also provided regarding the timely provision of documentation
requested in the initial inspection letter that is provided prior to the entrance meeting.
V. CONSULTATION
Consultation was offered in the area of best practice in communication between the
facility, architects and contractors with the Bureau of Fire Services pertaining to Plan
Review processes.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
3

The agency has not been required to submit any corrective action plans during this
period under review.
Financial Overview
An independent financial overview completed on 09/30/2024 for the previous year
was provided and reviewed. No concerns were noted and the organization
demonstrated sufficient financing.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator assessment was completed on 06/23/2025. The facility
did not have any Corrective Action Plans to review from this reporting period and
had one unplanned discharge to note.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff were interviewed during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility on
05/27/2025. Staff reported positive experiences working at the facility. They felt
well trained and supported by management. Newer staff remarked that they felt
like they were brought along in their orientation at the right pace, gaining
responsibility and one on one time with youth as they learned.
Youth was interviewed during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility on
05/27/2025. Youth felt safe at the facility. They remarked that the rules and
programming of the facility were well explained at the time of intake, and they had
the ability to have ample communication with their family while placed.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The facility was toured during an unannounced, face-to-face visit to the facility on
05/27/2025. No safety concerns were noted. The facility was in a clean and
organized condition. Cleaning items, medications and any other hazardous
materials were stored safely. The kitchen had ample food and supplies for youth.
Construction of the kitchen and recreation area has continued to be paused while
the Plan Review process is completed.
4

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
